issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in modifying clause 14 of the scheme to restrict the archakas' remuneration to only half share in dibbi collections and share in pumpkins and rice, excluding other customary emoluments and perquisites

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court modified the direction of the learned District Judge by stating The appellant seeks also the modification of clause  14  of the scheme in so far as it provides that the archakas shall be entitled to claim as and for their remuneration only half the share of the income from the dibbi installed in the temple and such other emoluments, perquisites etc., allowed under the decrees of Courts, or usage.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPEAL No. 531 OF 1961 This appeal, as stated earlier, relates to the remuneration payable to the Karnam who also holds his office by hereditary right. Under the scheme framed in O.S. 1 of 1925 the remuneration of the Karnam consisted of the payment to him of a 1/16th of the half share in the dibbi collections.

holdings.text: The appeal by the Board to the High Court from the order of the District Judge under s.57(9) modifying the scheme was competent.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the principle of the Full Bench decision cited does number apply to the application before us and that the appeal was companypetent. Section 57 of the Act deals with two types of cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order under s.57(9) modifies or cancels scheme-decree under s.92 CPC deemed scheme under s.75, hence itself a decree or amends prior decree per s.2(2) CPC, appealable under s.96 CPC; distinguishes s.84 Full Bench as different proceeding initiated by application not affecting prior decree.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in modifying clause 14 of the scheme to restrict archakas' remuneration to half dibbi share and pumpkins/rice; original clause 14 as framed by District Judge restored.

anchor.surface_text: Coming next to the merits of the decision of the High Court, learned companynsel for the appellant pointed out that there were seven families of archakas who held the office by hereditary right, who divided the share of the dibbi companylections and the other minor items between themselves.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No sufficient cause under s.57(9) shown; Board conceded half dibbi share in O.P., no pleadings/evidence/appeal grounds challenging other customary emoluments protected by s.79 and prior decrees/scheme; vagueness not alleged or proved, scheme worked 25+ years without issue.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in modifying paragraph 17 of the scheme to fix Karnam's salary at Rs.25 per mensem; paragraph 17 as framed by District Judge restored.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPEAL No. 531 OF 1961 This appeal, as stated earlier, relates to the remuneration payable to the Karnam who also holds his office by hereditary right. Under the scheme framed in O.S. 1 of 1925 the remuneration of the Karnam companysisted of the payment to him of a 1/16th of the half share in the dibbi companylections.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prayer to abolish office or fix nominal salary, only to adjust pay if deputy used; DJ balanced custom (personal duty for full share) with deputy approval; s.79 protects; executive officer does not eliminate Karnam duties; no sufficient cause on pleadings.

precedents.citation: Rajagopala Chettiar v. Hindu Religious Endowments Board 1

anchor.surface_text: In support of this submission reliance was placed on the decision of a Full Bench of the Madras High Court in Rajagopala Chettiar v. Hindu Religious Endowments Board 1 . Section 84 1  of the Act enacted If any dispute arises as to whether a math or temple is one to which this Act applies or as to whether a math or temple is an excepted temple, such dispute shall Be decided by the Board.

precedents.case_name: Rajagopala Chettiar v. Hindu Religious Endowments Board
precedents.cited_proposition: No appeal lies to the High Court from the order of the District Judge on an application under s.84(2) of the Act because it is not a decree under s.2(2) CPC and there is no specific provision for appeal in the Act.
precedents.cited_holding: The order of the District Court did not fall within the definition of a decree within s.2(2) of the Civil Procedure Code because the proceeding was an application and not a suit; consequently s.96 CPC was not attracted and no appeal lay absent specific provision.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 532 of 1961 is accordingly allowed and the original paragraph 14 of the scheme as framed by the learned District Judge is restored. The appellants are entitled to their costs in this Court,

outcome.relief_summary: Both Civil Appeals Nos. 531 and 532 of 1961 allowed; High Court modifications to clauses 14 and 17 of the scheme set aside; District Judge's provisions restored
directions: Restore original paragraph 14 of the scheme for archakas remuneration
Restore paragraph 17 of the scheme for karnam remuneration
Appellants in C.A. No. 532/1961 entitled to costs from respondents 1 and 2

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPEAL No. 531 OF 1961 This appeal, as stated earlier, relates to the remuneration payable to the Karnam who also holds his office by hereditary right. Under the scheme framed in O.S. 1 of 1925 the remuneration of the Karnam companysisted of the payment to him of a 1/16th of the half share in the dibbi companylections.

Civil Appeal No. 532 of 1961 is accordingly allowed and the original paragraph 14 of the scheme as framed by the learned District Judge is restored. The appellants are entitled to their costs in this Court,
